Issues.Title: Type checks by typescript fail on Vue.set/delete
Issues.Body:
### Version
2.5.17

### Reproduction link
[https://github.com/nel215/vue-sandbox](https://github.com/nel215/vue-sandbox)





### Steps to reproduce
```
$ git clone https://github.com/nel215/vue-sandbox.git
$ cd vue-sandbox
$ yarn
$ ./node_modules/.bin/tsc index.ts
index.ts:5:9 - error TS2345: Argument of type '{}' is not assignable to parameter of type '"a"[]'.
  Property 'length' is missing in type '{}'.

5 Vue.set(data.obj, 1, 'a')
          ~~~~~~~~

index.ts:6:12 - error TS2345: Argument of type '{}' is not assignable to parameter of type '{}[]'.
  Property 'length' is missing in type '{}'.

6 Vue.delete(data.obj, 1)
```

### What is expected?
Type checks by typescript succeed on this case.

### What is actually happening?
Type checks by typescript fail on this case.

---
Can we use number as key of object on Vue.set/delete? If it's yes, I will create a PR which fixes types/vue.d.ts.

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->

### Steps to reproduce

Issues.Title: Add support for optional components when using <component> tag
Issues.Body:
### What problem does this feature solve?

Currently when using `<component is="foo"></component>` syntax and the component `foo` doesn't exist an warning is produced:

>  vue.common.js:593 [Vue warn]: Unknown custom element: <foo> - did you register the component correctly? For recursive components, make sure to provide the "name" option.

I would like to propose an extension to allow optional components, which won't provide the warning if component doesn't exist.

### What does the proposed API look like?

1. Attribute which will prevent the warning:

       <component is="foo" optional></component>

2. Slot content rendered if component not found. This actually works, but is not documented. It would be nice to have it docs:

       <component is="foo" optional>Component not found</component>

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Add support for optional components when using <component> tag" (#8700)

Issues.Title: Cannot install Vuex on subclass due to missing static properties
Issues.Body:
### Version
2.5.17

### Reproduction link
[https://jsfiddle.net/n9jmu5v7/21025/](https://jsfiddle.net/n9jmu5v7/21025/)





### Steps to reproduce
Open the reproducer and look in the console to see the errors

### What is expected?
Vuex should successfully be installed on the Vue subclass

### What is actually happening?
Due to the dependency on static properties that are not copied, errors are thrown

---
We're attempting to use VueX in a component library without exposing it outside of the boundaries of our library and ran into this bug when attempting to install VueX globally on a subclass that would be specific to our library.

Based on the code, it seems like it's intended that one should be able to call `.use` on a subclass and have that plugin be isolated to the subclass.

I'm not sure exactly where this should be considered a bug or where a patch should be made.  VueX is using `Vue.version` and `Vue.config` internally which are both part of the public API, but are not copied to the subclass when doing `Vue.extend`.  We could also make VueX traverse the inheritance/prototype chain until it reaches the root Vue class and pull the properties from there.

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Cannot install Vuex on subclass due to missing static properties" (#8690)

Issues.Title: new Vue() event bus doesn't delete _events keys on event removal
Issues.Body:
### Version
2.5.17

### Reproduction link
[https://jsfiddle.net/Laeticia/mqo5fy7p/2/](https://jsfiddle.net/Laeticia/mqo5fy7p/2/)





### Steps to reproduce
Create global event bus (new Vue), add event listener using eventBus.$on, then remove the listener using eventBus.$off.  The eventBus._events object will still contain the event name with value null, rather than deleting the event name property.

In jsFiddle, click Add Event Listener and Remove Event Listener buttons.  The _events object is displayed in the jsfiddle and also in the javascript console after adding and removing listeners.

### What is expected?
After removing an event listener, I expect that event name to be removed from the global event bus (Vue) _events object.

### What is actually happening?
The event name is still in the _events object with value null.

---
When using a lot of unique event names, although the app tries to clean up the events via eventBus.$off, the event names are still in the _events object.  Unless these null properties get cleaned up at some point, it appears to be a memory leak.

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "new Vue() event bus doesn't delete _events keys on event removal" (#8696)

Issues.Title: `Duplicate keys detected` in v-for if using a functional component
Issues.Body:
### Version
2.5.17

### Reproduction link
[https://codesandbox.io/s/986x7y34v4?expanddevtools=1](https://codesandbox.io/s/986x7y34v4?expanddevtools=1)





### Steps to reproduce
First of all, this is the first Issue I've created on this project. So I'll take this opportunity to thank all of the contributors and maintainers for the awesome and astonishing work they do for Vue. THANKS!

Having a functional component and trying to use it inside a v-for produces a `Duplicate keys detected` error, even if using :key="<unique identifier>". It's fixable by just converting the component to a non-functional one.

According to my understanding of functional components and the way :key="" works, even functional components (without a state) should be :key-able, as that isn't related to the state of the component itself.

According to Chris Fritz (https://twitter.com/ivansieder/status/1030374407515058177) the issue is also present in earlier versions.

### What is expected?
The v-for renders the component without any error.

### What is actually happening?
The v-for renders the component with a `Duplicate keys detected` error.

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->

Issues.Title: Two feature to make history.state more useful
Issues.Body:
### What problem does this feature solve?
1) Run replaceState when app init
`history.state.key` is a very useful value. But `history.state` is null when app init.
Although manually run `router.replace` when app created is ok, guards like `router.beforeEach` will run twice, which is not expected.

2) Change `history.state.key` when replaceState
Generally, PageA replace to PageB, keep history.state the same key is fine.
But in this case: PageA -> PageB -> replace to PageC -> back to PageA -> replaceTo PageD ----- It's expected that PageD use the same key with PageA, but actually same with PageB & PageC.
A solution is to change `history.state.key` when replaceState. So that all page-jump will generate a new key.

### What does the proposed API look like?
no need

Issues.Title: There's a potential collision between state keys
Issues.Body:
### Version
3.0.1

### Reproduction link
[https://github.com/vuejs/vue-router/blob/90cd2690d59c6bd56e5bc12b5b752166a1d35e98/src/util/push-state.js#L22-L30](https://github.com/vuejs/vue-router/blob/90cd2690d59c6bd56e5bc12b5b752166a1d35e98/src/util/push-state.js#L22-L30)

### Steps to reproduce
``` js
console.log(window.history.state.key) // 2078.800

// refresh window and try again
console.log(window.history.state.key) // 1678.300

// refresh window and try again
console.log(window.history.state.key) // 2263.300

// ...repeat

// refresh window and try again
console.log(window.history.state.key) // 1678.300 - collision
```

### What is expected?
unique value

### What is actually happening?
collision

---
Because of Spectre issue, each browser reduced the resolution of `performance.now()`. For example, [FireFox's precision is only 2ms](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Performance/now#Reduced_time_precision).

[It doesn't a problem in a single Vue instance lifecycle](https://github.com/vuejs/vue-router/pull/998#issuecomment-265549456).

But there may be multiple Vue instances in the whole session history, and keys between them could collide.

Please replace `performance.now()` with `Date.now()` or [uuid](https://github.com/kelektiv/node-uuid).
<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "There's a potential collision between state keys" (#2349)

Issues.Title: trying to update query parameters
Issues.Body:
### Version
3.0.1 (nuxtjs 1.4)

### Reproduction link
[gist](https://gist.github.com/acidjazz/95c5b7728a759fbd09fdfe61f84ccd8f)

### Steps to reproduce
I've read the documentation repeatedly, read every stack overflow, and gone through all of the Vue forums on anything related to programatic navigation for over a year now and i've never been able to do the following successfully

1. pass a this=that query parameter into `this.$route.query`, using either `.push`, `.replace`, etc
2. have `this.$route.query` instantly contain that new parameter
3. have my URL also reflect that change/add/removal of the parameter

here is one of my current methods I use that "kind of" works in one of my projects

```js
methods: {
    query (params) {
      let i = 0
      for (let key in params) {
        setTimeout(() => {
          this.$router.push({ query: {...this.$route.query, [key]: params[key] }})
        } , 100*++i) 
      }
      setTimeout(() => this.get(), 100*++i)
    },
}
```
I simply call `query({page: 2})` and pray, `this.get()` is just an axios get to the API passing `this.$route.params`, then refreshing the data

### What is expected?
my parameters to update both in `this.$route.query` and the URL

### What is actually happening?
If I don't add these delays, the behavior is pretty radical, one of the following and/or all happens
1. `this.$route.query` does not have any, or some of the parameters passed through
2. The URL does not show or reflect some of the parameters
3. `1.` will happen to different parameters than `2.`  
4. Safari is most likely not to work, requires a larger increase of delays


### Why is this a GitHub issue?
My main goal with posting this is not just to finally find a solid stable solution to my issue, but afterwards do all I can to shorten this path for others in the future.

Issues.Title: vue-router does not destroy itself
Issues.Body:
### Version
3.0.1

### Reproduction link
[https://jsfiddle.net/se6gLaqn/1/](https://jsfiddle.net/se6gLaqn/1/)

### Steps to reproduce
Create a vue instance, as well as a router instance. Then destroy the vue instance. 

The router instance continues to exist and fire.

### What is expected?
The router should be able to properly destroy itself; either by explicit call, or when the vue instance is destroyed

### What is actually happening?
The router exists and cannot be destroyed

---
I did some googling and see that vue-router cannot currently be destroyed, but I am asking for reconsideration. Unlike the other issue I found (https://github.com/vuejs/vue-router/issues/954) where it appeared the user wanted to destroy and create a new router in the same application, the issue I am having is completely separate. 

I have a massive application that essentially uses pjax methodologies to be able to run several SPAs (vue being one) that create the full site. When we navigate away from one SPA to another, the SPA needs to destroy itself so it's code does not interfere with the other SPAs. However, because the vue router cannot be destroyed; it's attempting to execute logic for routing even when the SPA that created it is destroyed. The issue compounds when we have more than 1 vue application running, as there are now 2 instances of vue-router (or more) running at a time. 

Specifically, we are using the hash version of routing. It looks like the router just attaches an event to the window and listens for popstates, but things get weird when more than one event does something with popstate (an understandably oddball behavior).  I would appreciate reconsideration for allowing vue-router to destroy itself when appropriate. Thanks!

[edited for spelling/grammar]

Issues.Title: TypeScript `watch` doesn't support getters parameter for getter
Issues.Body:
### Version
3.0.1

### Reproduction link
[https://codepen.io/anon/pen/LBexJp?editors=0010#0](https://codepen.io/anon/pen/LBexJp?editors=0010#0)

### Steps to reproduce
- Use TypeScript to define your store.
- Use `store.watch` with a getter that accepts getters as the second argument (as described in the Vuex docs)
- Observe typescript error "Argument of type '(_state: any, getters: any) => any' is not assignable to parameter of type '(state: { n: number; }) => any'."

### What is expected?
Vuex recognizes the getter as valid, still types `state`, and preferably types `getters`.

Issues.Title: Dynamically registered modules during SSR getting lost on client side state replacement
Issues.Body:
If you register store module during SSR (e.g. store.registerModule('name', storeModule); ) and then do store state replacement on the client side (e.g. store.replaceState(window.__INITIAL_STATE__); ), none of the module methods is accessible from within the component throwing an error (module namespace not found in mapGetters/mapState/-//- ).

Pure client or server side works fine, but hydration seems to break.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Dynamically registered modules during SSR getting lost on client side state replacement" (#1351)
